Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2009 07:10AM Jellydonut wrote: Are you talking UTI's?  If you are, one major cause is lack of estrogen.  I had a serious UTI which lasted about two months despite multiple antibiotics and diflucan; visits to the ER, the uriologist, etcl, the bugger just did not want to leave me!  After that bout I decided to go back on estrogen at a very low dose am and glad I did.  It's been about 2.5 years and I'm feeling better than ever.   I understand it's a very personal decision and it's not for everyone.  The surgeon told me he has a "few" women who've decided to take estrogen after a BC diagnosis due to quality of life.  The oncologist, on the other hand, does not like it at all!  He gave me a hard time about my decision but seems to be taking it in stride. Wishing you the best, Jelly

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2008 12:27AM Jellydonut wrote: Shelray, I've had one PET in 6.5 years (done last year) and I don't intend to have another unless I'm having problems. As I've posted in another thread, we'll be seeing less of these tests getting approval from insurance because they are looking to cut costs.  Talk to your doc about this when you see him and get his take on it.  Some onc's only order PET's if there are problems (high tumor markers; pain, etc).  There really isn't a "rule book" so to speak that each onc and/or surgeon adheres to.  Sorry you had to have so many surgeries!!  You poor dear.  Take good care of yourself. Jelly
Posts.Title: PET scan??? shelray Jellydonut

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 02:09AM - edited Dec 9, 2008 02:10AM by Jellydonut Tek, For most of us tumor markers do vary and usually doctors don't consider it a problem unless it escalates a lot (say from 50 to 500, or a steady increase over a period of months, 50-175-300).  It's up to you if you wish to take the PET scan.  You don't have to agree just because the doctor is suggesting it.  It's really your choice.  Is this your first PET scan?  If it is, it's good to use as a baseline scan - something to compare to down the line. Good luck, Jelly
Posts.Title: PET scan??? shelray Jellydonut

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2008 03:07AM - edited Dec 8, 2008 12:32PM by Jellydonut Hi Shelray, Yes, there is a blood test (known as a tumor marker test, or tumor markers) called CA 27-29.  It measures the CA27-29 antigen in the blood (hence the name of the test), but it is not accurate for everyone.  Some oncs use tumor markers and some don't.  There are other blood tests such as CEA and another one that escapes me at this moment . I'm linking to Dr Susan Love's site on her take on CA 27-29.  She explains it much better than I. http://www.dslrf.org/breastcancer/content.asp?L2=4&L3=7&SID=132&CID=591&PID=0 As you can see, we don't yet have one tool, one scan or one blood test that is relevant for everyone.  Some things work for some people and some oncs don't use any of it until a problem arises.  This can be a little disconcerting at times but try not to let it get to you.  As time passes, better "things" will come along for detection.  Hugs, Jelly

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2008 03:36PM - edited Sep 1, 2008 05:48PM by Jellydonut River, Certainly fertility drugs are a possibility....but....breast cancer dates back to the beginning of time, long before IVF, HRT, parabens, drug companies, pesticides etc., etc. I took Premain for 20 years and I used to swear it was the cause of my cancer but after reading way too much about BC, and the history of BC my thought now is the cause(s) is STILL UNKNOWN!  "Bathsheba's Breast" is one book that details the history of BC.  It's well written but not easy to read.  There are parts where I found myself in tears for what BC women have had to endure through the ages. Probably, it will come down to genetics - but we're not there yet.... Jelly

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2010 01:27AM Jellydonut wrote: Judi, Best of luck with the estrogen and I hope it's as good and effective for you as it's been for me.  I've been on estrogen since  late 2006, after my second recurrence in the same breast.  At the time, with two back-to-back recurrences, I thought my life was coming to an end and decided that I was going to leave "happy", so I asked the surgeon to prescribe premarin.  He did.  A few months later I went on bioidentical estrogen but that is no longer available through my prescription program, so I now take Estrogel. As you can see, I'm still here three years later and have not had any side effects at all.  In my 20's I had a hysterectomy -- so those "parts" were not a worry on estrogen.  My oncologist is stumped as to why it hasn't killed me yet.  I had a total of four tumors and all were 95% ER+. Jelly
Posts.Title: Estrogen Therapy? Bad news just now. Judiiiii Jellydonut

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2010 02:59AM - edited Jan 30, 2010 11:33AM by Jellydonut I'm sure my doc does know about estrogen therapy now, but don't think he knew of it in '07 when I began seeing him.  He was not happy about my choice of taking it stating it could kill me. He asked if I was taking it for "libido" and I laughed.  No husband, no boyfriend -- what libido? LOL In '07 a scan showed a small "growth" on my lung and several "spots" on my bones.  Of course it stressed me out but since I cannot and will not ever have chemo, I decided on no further testing and no further scans until I'm in pain.  So far, so good.  I'm still walking and breathing.  On my last Onc visit, he said I can see him once a year instead of twice since I'm doing well. I do know this disease will kill me (I do have a heart condition too, so it's possible that can get me first) and it's just a matter of time. Really, really hoping and praying that estrogen is a miracle drug for you! Jelly

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2008 09:43PM - edited Aug 6, 2008 08:59AM by Jellydonut Hi Danyel, Sorry to hear you encountered this jerk of an oncologist.  My suggestion is if at all possible obtain a second opinion.  This jerk lacks common sense and compassion, two traits that are essential when treating cancer patients.  According to your description he also lacks good judgement by bringing up the subject of recurrence.  There isn't a reason in the world (unless you specifically asked about recurrence) for an oncologist to bring up such an awful thing during the first visit.  He is just a man with a medical degree, not a god and it sounds to me like he gives this same spiel by rote, instead of treating the patient as an individual. I've encountered a few doctors of his ilk early in my diagnosis and remember feeling worse when I left their office, due to their behavior and not the cancer.  This is your life and you deserve to be treated by a doctor who understands you're a human being  and will treat the whole person along with the cancer. You came to a good place with your questions and fears.  The women here are kind, knowledable and helpful. Sending you a rainbow of good tidings and wishing you great success with chemo and the new onc! Jelly

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2008 06:22PM - edited Apr 2, 2008 06:25PM by Jellydonut Hello Jade, So sorry to hear of your diagnosis and subsequent mastectomy.  8.5cm is considered a large tumor, but not all that uncommon.  Cancer is in our bodies for a time before it is discovered.  Do double check with your surgeon to ensure the report (and size of tumor) is accurate. You also may want to ask what grade the cancer is (which IMO is more important than the size of the tumor.) "Getting it all" is an expression that is not used any longer.  There may be cells floating around that cannot be detected, but please don't focus on that aspect, just focus on your chemo and doing all you can to combat the cancer. I also had three positive nodes (along with a tumor and a nodule) six years ago and I'm fine today. The very best to you and come back here as often as you see fit.  We have a great and very supportive group of women here who will help you through. Jelly

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2009 09:12PM - edited Jul 4, 2009 09:13PM by Jellydonut Your description is exact to the way I was after my first lumpectomy.  I could not bear the thought of looking at my cut up breast.  After about four months of avoiding the issue, one day I decided to look, and after that I was okay (okay as one can be with a cut up breast.) Then after 4 years or so came the bilateral mastectomy and once again was freightened out of my mind to look at my chest.  Not sure how long it took this time but eventually I found the courage to see what I looked like without breasts, and although not liking it at all, I did come to terms with the new look.  I will be having reconstruction soon (after 2.5 years of being without breasts) and I'm happy about my decision. There is not a set time limit of what is best for you.  When you're ready to look you'll know it -- just know that you're not alone with this issue. Wishing you the best, Jelly

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2008 06:25AM Jellydonut wrote: Ladies, Realize that a mastectomy is major surgery and each of us recuperates at an individual pace.  Don't be hard on yourselves, in time you will feel much better and stronger.  Try to rest as much as possible and eating protein is also recommended to regain strength. Before the Internet, people recovered at their own rate and accepted that.  Nowadays, we're aware of some who regain strength and energy quickly and digest that as the norm.  It is not.  Accept what your body is telling you and rest, relax, eat well and take the pain meds if necessary.  Wishing you ladies all the best, Jelly
Posts.Title: Frustrated With Recovery flb1011 2Hands4me

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2009 08:23PM - edited Jan 5, 2009 08:25PM by Jellydonut Gosh, I'm feeling guilty because on some other threads I'd stated that I had an "easy" recovery from the bilateral mastectomy (no reconstruction.)  Well, I'm going to delete those threads tonight because it's the wrong thing to say. What I had not mentioned in those thread was that I took eight weeks off from work to recover.  Eight total weeks of rest, no stress, sleeping when I felt tired, leisurely going through the day, reading, relaxing and eating protein/vegetables.  When I finally did go back to work (full time) the first few weeks were hard on my body and I felt like a truck ran over me. I would come home and get in bed for the night - at 5:00 PM!! I've had many, many surgeries in life starting at age 19 (most not cancer related) and to be honest, I'm glad back then that I was totally unaware of how "easy" someone else's recuperation may have been because I might have wanted to punch them in the eye .   In all but one of the surgeries, I took my time and took it easy until my body was ready to "go."   With the first lumpectomy/SNB/AND my life was not going well and I had no choice but to get back to work ASAP.  It was a nightmare; pain, fatigue, feeling sore and miserable, plus the emotional turmoil of knowing I had cancer. A few times I left work early just due to extreme fatigue and crying jags.  That recovery took a long time, much longer than it would have if I had had the rest and relaxation required after a surgery. You will feel better in time - however long your body needs to recuperate.  Don't try to rush it!!  I did not have physical therapy but I understand that it is very helpful for mastectomy patients.  If it is something feasible for you to do then by all means, do it. Wishing you ladies all the best, Jelly

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2008 06:49PM Jellydonut wrote: Any time there are massive amounts of money available - there is waste.  We've seen this with Katrina, World Trade Center and now this financial fiasco.  Granted, breast cancer is a matter of life and death, but it appears to me that these huge funds can be better spent.  Nowadays, everybody and their dog wants a grant (and a percentage succeed) for something to do with breast cancer because the funds are readily available.  How about a few years ago the announcement that broccoli can halt cancer (or something to the effect)?  There are many other bizarre studies that women post here that seem to me like throwing money out the window.  I'm still awaiting the day that each and every grant is listed or catagorized stating the purpose; cost and results.  We may get the purpose and results but the only time I've seen the cost is on Dr. Love's Foundation website. There was a time in my life that I managed academic grants (non-medical) and the largest cost by far is salaries/benefits, followed by materials/supplies (desks, computes, materials, etc.)  We, at the time, held a very tight string on spending and adherence to the specifics of the grant - meaing - no big holiday bash paid by grants funds, etc. I was both elated and forlorn with the movie "Living Proof."  Elated, of course because the drug is successful for millions of women.  Forlorn and even angry of the hospital/drug company politics that got in the way and delayed what has become a miracle drug for many.  Even worse, was when Mrs. Tartikoff took it upon herself to plead to Revlon for the big initial funding.  WTF (excuse me!!!!)  It's wonderful that Mr. Ron Perlman and his Revlon Board agreed to fork over 2.4 million, but what if they did not?  Why didn't Dr. Slamon (sp?) get a grant or many grants?? IMHO, politics injects itself into BC research and those who do are too small of beings to do the right thing because it's the right thing to do.  Okay, off the soapbox for now! Jelly

Posts.Content: Jellydonut wrote: From the FDA site: http://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm233863.htm FDA NEWS RELEASE For Immediate Release: Nov. 15, 2010 Media Inquiries: Erica Jefferson, 301-796-4988, erica.jefferson@fda.hhs.gov Consumer Inquiries: 888-INFO-FDA FDA approves new treatment option for late-stage breast cancer The U.S. Food and Drug Administration today approved Halaven (eribulin mesylate) to treat patients with metastatic breast cancer who have received at least two prior chemotherapy regimens for late-stage disease. Breast cancer is the second leading cause of cancer related death among women, according to the National Cancer Institute. This year, an estimated 207,090 women will be diagnosed with breast cancer, while 39,840 women will die from the disease. Halaven is a synthetic form of a chemotherapeutically active compound derived from the sea sponge Halichondria okadai. This injectable therapy is a microtubule inhibitor, believed to work by inhibiting cancer cell growth. Before receiving Halaven, patients should have received prior anthracycline- and taxane-based chemotherapy for early or late-stage breast cancer. Halaven's safety and effectiveness were established in a single study in 762 women with metastatic breast cancer who had received at least two prior chemotherapy regimens for late-stage disease. Patients were randomly assigned to receive treatment with either Halaven or a different single agent therapy chosen by their oncologist. The study was designed to measure the length of time from when this treatment started until a patient's death (overall survival). The median overall survival for patients receiving Halaven was 13.1 months compared with 10.6 months for those who received a single agent therapy. "There are limited treatment options for women with aggressive forms of late-stage breast cancer who have already received other therapies," said Richard Pazdur, M.D., director of the Office of Oncology Drug Products in the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research. "Halaven shows a clear survival benefit and is an important new option for women." The most common side effects reported by women treated with Halaven include a decrease in infection-fighting white blood cells (neutropenia), anemia, a decrease in the number of white blood cells (leukopenia), hair loss (alopecia), fatigue, nausea, weakness (asthenia), nerve damage (peripheral neuropathy), and constipation. Other FDA-approved therapies used to treat late-stage, refractory breast cancer include Xeloda (capecitabine) for patients with breast cancer resistant to paclitaxel and anthracycline-containing chemotherapy; Ixempra (ixabepilone) for patients with late-stage disease after failure of an anthracycline, taxane and Xeloda; and Ixempra plus Xeloda for patients with late-stage disease after failure of anthracycline- and taxane-based chemotherapy. Halaven is marketed by Woodcliff Lakes, N.J. -based Eisai Inc. For more information: FDA: Office of Oncology Drug Products   NCI: Breast Cancer Dx 3/2002, IDC, Stage IV, 3/8 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2009 01:52PM Jellydonut wrote: I would suggest asking for a visiting nurse, if insurance allows, to check your Mom's incision, drains, et al, post surgery.  The drains need to be emptied a few times daily (for the first few days) and the drainage measured (most of us had drains so I'm assuming your Mom will too).  I live alone and did have the visiting nurse twice.  Since I was doing fine she and I agreed it was not necessary for her to keep a check on me.  I was very able to take care of the drains on my own (it sounds worse than it really is.) Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2008 08:59PM Jellydonut wrote: Charity Care usually picks up the tab for the uninsured who don't have any assets.  However, it's my thought that they (the uninsured) do not get nearly as good care as those who are insured, (excluding Medicaid insurance.)  Medicaid is maybe a small step up from no insurance and most (private) doctors do not accept it due to very low payments.  Also with Medicaid, scans are prohibited due to cost.  In essence, the uninsured and under-insured are getting bare bones medical care and more often than not, are treated with disrespect. In the US, this medical mess we're in is a behemoth and complicated problem and it would shock me if there is a viable solution anytime soon.  If universal healthcare took effect tomorrow, some or most of the (almost) 50 million uninsured may decide to see a doctor within a month or two and there are not nearly enough doctors to fill this need.  It would create total chaos and impact each and every one of us.  I've been uninsured and it's no picnic, but a system like Canada's does not seem like the panacea.  Certainly, I hope some team of brilliant people (like Mensa members, doctors, financial gurus, insurance people, etc.) can initiate something that is fair and just, and will solve this awful problem.

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 07:51PM Jellydonut wrote: Hi Jen, Glad your lumpectomy is over!  That's a step in the right direction Pain/numbness two weeks later is very normal for most.  The numbness may last quite a while.  It's best to use an electric razor to shave underarms while numb.  I remember going back to work after a week and still being in pain and I had numbness for quite a long time.  Of course, we're all different and pain/numbness differ from person to person.  As Lainey suggested, it also depends where the incisions are located.  I was quite surprised (in a bad way) that I was in so much pain afterwards and had numbness, but eventually, it did subside.  I had lumpectomy, SNB and AND, so perhaps that was the reason.  My initial tumor was at the "2:00" position and the scar was large. It is best to speak to your doctor and get his take.  If the pain is bad and you have pain meds do take them.  I was a total dope and refused to take the pain meds and suffered neednessly. My best to you for a full recovery, Jelly

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2010 08:54PM - edited Jul 31, 2010 08:57PM by Jellydonut Peggy,  It's been my experience that most male doctors either don't realize or understand (or both) the propensity of suffering that UTI's cause.  It's horrible! She may need Diflucan, and probably more than one dose, but only if she does not have liver mets as that drug can be hard on the liver. Probiotics (bought at a health food store) along with cranberry vitamins (as opposed to the juice which has tons of sugar in it) and a good strong cream for the vaginal area are all benefical (but of course check with her doctor first).  The cream I have is: Nystatin and Triamcinolone Acetonide Cream USP (by prescription) -- it's the Big Daddy of creams and is very effective, and works quickly to relieve the burning and itching.  Some type of estrogen (in cream or gel form) for a short amount of time may greatly benefit her too. It's best for her to refrain from eating anything with sugar until this bugger clears up. I'm not a doctor, but am just relaying what's worked for me in the past when I suffered with many of those infections, including one time when I went to the ER twice in the same day.  It's one of the reasons I went back on estrogen and I've been okay ever since. I hope she encounters a doctor that knows how to treat this type of infection -- and quick! Wishing her the best and fast relief.

Posts.Content: Dec 25, 2008 07:48PM Jellydonut wrote: Radiant, Not sure if you can order this test on your own, but do know it runs about $600.  At least that's what my insurance was billed.  I've had the test four times over a few year period and it's always zero.  Funny thing is I think I'm the only patient at the cancer center that has this test  performed and there are about 7 oncs there with hundreds of patients.  Each & every time I call for the results no one knows how to read them and have to either wait for the onc to call me back, or if I'm in work I have the results faxed to me.  I've become very adept at reading them and the last time even taught the nurse how to read them over the phone.  She thanked me and said she's never seen this test before.  It's my belief that the use of this test is not widespread and though I like "zero" I find the results questionable. I don't know of any kit that you can purchase on your own plus you would  need to draw blood  ) .  That would be enough for me to not do it on my own. Jelly

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2007 08:52AM - edited Dec 2, 2007 08:53AM by Jellydonut Sorry you're going through this ordeal for a second time. I'm a big proponent of everything disposable for a hospital stay due to germs.  I did pack a robe and used it, but stayed in the hospital gown; used their slipper socks and the other disposable items provided by the hospital, then threw them in the trash when leaving. When I came home the robe and the clothes I wore home went right into the laundry. Although it may sound ridiculous, when you get home wipe your cell phone, handbag, suitcase, etc. with alcohol or antibacterial wipes.  You want to do everything in your power to prevent a staph or even worse, MRSA infection.  In addition, you may want to pack your own hand sanitizer for yourself, guests', doctors & nurses to use.  In some hospitals these dispensers are in every room, but I'm not sure how often the personnel partake. Best of luck on your surgery and recovery.

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2009 06:20PM - edited Aug 4, 2009 04:25PM by Jellydonut Hi Christina, Right now what you know for certain is that you have a lump in your breast that needs a biopsy.  It isn't cancer unless the pathology report states it's cancer -- and surely there is a chance that it is not.  We all hope the latter for you. It depends on the surgeon as to the type of biopsy you will have.  Mine was a fine needle aspiration (FNA)  done in the dr's office, and it was virtually painless and over quickly.  I don't subscribe to the theory of a biopsy spreading the cancer and I believe it to be an old wives' tale.  It is not better to leave it alone!  You do need to know for certain one way or the other. Some of our wonderful women on this site will come by with their stories and encouragement. It's so awful that you're now dealing with this issue on top of everything else.  It just doesn't seem fair. We're here for you.  Please let us know how you are and how your appointment goes on Thursday.  All good wishes are with you. Hugs (((()))) Jelly
